summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various judges and SEC officials, primarily dated May 21, 2021, with earlier threads from 2020. Dilorio alleges massive, ongoing securities fraud involving naked short selling, money laundering, and SEC obstruction. He specifically implicates Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE), UBS, Jefferies, and others in a criminal enterprise facilitated by corrupt SEC officials. The emails serve as a formal appeal against the SEC's denial of his whistleblower award claim for the Oppenheimer AML action (2015-016).

connections.description: Handler/Jefferies repeatedly bailed out the allegedly criminal entity NITE (Knight/KCG) according to Dilorio's allegations.
Both worked at Sullivan Cromwell, which advised Knight/KCG/Virtu transactions, allegedly facilitating fraud.
Alleged to have traded billions of shares in the same OTCM money laundering shells (e.g., CGFIA, AppTech) in a symbiotic naked shorting/money laundering scheme.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: The so-called trading 'glitch' at Knight Capital that caused a $440 million loss. Dilorio alleges it was not a glitch but proof of Knight's insolvency and massive accounting fraud due to naked short fails, and that it triggered an SEC-orchestrated bailout.

events.title: Getco-Knight Reverse Merger Closes
events.description: The reverse merger between Getco and Knight Capital to form KCG Holdings closed. Dilorio alleges this was a bailout of a criminal enterprise, not a legitimate merger.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action (2015-016)
events.description: The SEC brought an anti-money laundering enforcement action against Oppenheimer & Co. Inc. Dilorio claims this action was based on his whistleblower information but the SEC denied him an award.

events.title: Virtu Financial Acquires KCG
events.description: Virtu Financial acquired KCG Holdings. Dilorio alleges massive fraud: Virtu CEO Cifu refused to disclose KCG's Q2 2017 financials and wrote down over $4 billion in naked short fails, grossly overpaying for an insolvent company.

events.title: SEC Charges Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: The SEC charged Joshua Sason, Marc Manuel, and others for microcap fraud and unlawful offerings related to NewLead and other shells. Dilorio claims this was his information from earlier TCRs.

events.title: SEC Reg SHO Complaint Against BTIG
events.description: The SEC filed a Regulation SHO complaint against BTIG for mis-marking short sales as long. Dilorio contrasts this with no action against Virtu for similar alleged conduct in 2017.

events.title: Dilorio's Formal Appeal Email
events.description: Christopher Dilorio sends a comprehensive email to Judge Swain and others, forwarding his formal appeal of the SEC's preliminary denial of his whistleblower award for the Oppenheimer action, detailing years of alleged fraud and obstruction.

locations: Miami, FL (Oleg Firer residence, various shell companies)
keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (entity referred to as 'NITE') is a criminal enterprise whose core business is abusive naked short selling of OTC market shells to facilitate money laundering, and that it has been in a constant state of insolvency.

Dilorio claims the SEC has criminally obstructed investigations into his allegations since 2011, actively facilitating the ongoing fraud by bailing out Knight after the 2012 'glitch' and allowing the fraudulent Virtu-KCG merger to proceed in 2017.

Key figures implicated in the alleged scheme and cover-up include Jefferies CEO Rich Handler, Virtu CEO Douglas Cifu, former SEC Chair Jay Clayton, his former Sullivan Cromwell colleague Jared Fishman, and SEC IG Carl Hoecker.

Dilorio provides specific evidence, citing a 2013 CGFIA 10-Q filing that mentions a 'Global Lock' due to actions by a 'third-party broker-dealer' as irrefutable proof of naked shorting, which the SEC allegedly ignored.

The emails frame the SEC's denial of Dilorio's whistleblower award for the Oppenheimer AML action as part of the obstruction, using a 'fabricated' reason that investigators never saw his information, despite the OWB's explicit responsibility to distribute such tips.
